area_name: Charlie Dome and The Lony Tusk

content.description: A low crux, an easy run-out, and nice knobs up high.
content.location: On east face near SE corner of Charlie Dome.

content.description:
In the center of the west face of the Tusk, an unlikely-looking, over-hanging start does in fact have enough holds to go. Fierce pulling on sharp holds leads to a break.  Above the break, pretty knobs lead to the top. 

  5.11+ may be a sandbag.
content.location: Center of west face of Tusk.

content.description: Nice knob climbing.  Leads to summit of Tusk. Shady in morning.

Just right of Lust In The Dust is a line of flakes heading up to the highest point of the Tusk.  A difficult (though reach-dependent) boulder move right off the deck can be avoided by A0 off the first bolt.  Somewhat strenuous, slightly over-hanging liebacking up the flakes leads to a ledge.  Above the ledge, pretty knobs on not-so-easy ground lead to the anchor.  If you do the boulder start you could call it 5.11.
content.location: Just right of Lust In The Dust.

content.description: On the right side of the west face of the Tusk a very pretty line drifts left, then up to the top. Tricky crux, the solution of which prompted the name.
content.location: Right side of W face of Tusk.

content.description: Easy but fun start leads to a tricky over-hanging headwall.
content.location: On the right side of the south face of Charlie Dome.

pathTokens: Charlie Dome and The Lony Tusk

content.description:
A large dome and a free-standing tower about 1/4 mile SSW of The Steep.  Named for CP (Charles) Little with whom I visited the area in 2005.  We thought there might be some really steep stone there judging from Google Earth, but no such luck.  We found a few bolts already there, and assumed that Tony Lusk had been there already.  No big surprise. 

  I went back in 2012 with Joe Shiefman and Jeremy Parks.  We did a couple of Tony's routes and put up a few more. 

  The routes are not fantastic but they are pretty good and it's a cool spot.  You will find solitude there... it's too far off the track to see anyone else.  AND...Lust In The Dust, Ivory Tower, Master Debater and Double Or Nothing have deep morning shade. 

  The Lony Tusk is yet another crag in the upper Sabino area that requires technical climbing to reach the summit.  The others are The Steep and Delta Dome.  It is quite likely that Tony was the first person to stand atop each of these crags.
